study.title: Post-caesarean section surgical site infections at a Tanzanian tertiary hospital: a prospective observational study

design.inclusion_criteria_text: All pregnant women admitted to the DRRH Labour Ward who underwent an elective or emergency CS were eligible for enrolment within 24 h post CS.

eligibility.population: All pregnant women who underwent an elective or emergency Caesarean Section.
eligibility.intervention: Observational study. Existing antibiotic practices described include a three-day course of intravenous ceftriaxone plus metronidazole followed by oral ampicillin/cloxacillin plus metronidazole, typically administered post-operatively.
eligibility.comparator: No formal comparator. Pre-incision prophylaxis was rare (2.1% of patients).

populations.description: All pregnant women undergoing Caesarean section who were successfully followed up for 30 days.
populations.comorbidities_key: HIV positive: 17/455 tested (3.7%). Diabetes screening performed in 236/467 (50.5%) women. Premature rupture of membranes (PROM): 11/467 (2.4%).

definitions.resistance_definition_text: Antimicrobial susceptibility of isolates was determined using disc diffusion. MRSA was identified by using the diffusion method with oxacillin disc.
definitions.outcome_definitions_text: SSIs were classified according to CDC definitions.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: A bacteriological swab was obtained, where possible, in every case of clinical suspicion of SSI by collecting the exudates from the open discharging wound.
lab_methods.culture_method: Specimens were inoculated on Blood agar and MacConkey agar and incubated aerobically. Petri dishes were checked after 24 and 48 h.

ssi_incidence.notes: The numerator (138) is for superficial SSIs among the 225 total SSIs. The denominator is the total cohort size.
The numerator (69) is for deep SSIs among the 225 total SSIs. The denominator is the total cohort size.
The numerator (5) is for organ/space SSIs among the 225 total SSIs. The denominator is the total cohort size.

amr_proportions.notes: Resistance to oxacillin is used to define Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

length_of_stay.notes: This is the average post-operative length of stay for the entire followed-up cohort, not stratified by SSI status.

risk_factors_effects.exposure: Senior doctor performing CS (vs. Junior doctor)
risk_factors_effects.notes: Univariate analysis. The text mentions this association did not remain significant in multivariate analysis (data not shown).
Univariate analysis, p < 0.001. The text mentions this association did not remain significant in multivariate analysis (data not shown).
Univariate analysis, p < 0.001 from Table II (continued).

interventions.description: The paper notes that based on this study's findings, 'An intervention to implement evidence-based revisions of the surgical procedures and antibiotic prophylaxis at the DRRH Gynaecology and Obstetrics Department is continuing'.

policy_capacity.status_text: No consistent protocol for the administration of antibiotic prophylaxis is available; antimicrobials are usually administered after the operation, and the choice depends on individual clinician’s preference.
Surgical procedures performed by junior doctors (interns) were associated with a higher risk of SSI. The authors recommend on-the-job training and supervision.

codes.summary: The study documented an extremely high incidence of post-caesarean section SSI at 48.2%, which is substantially higher than other reports from the same country, indicating a significant local burden of infection.

evidence_quotes.quote: The detected incidence rate of post-CS SSI was extremely high, at 48.2%. A recent report from Tanzania documented a more than four-fold lower incidence of post-CS SSI compared with our study (10.9% vs 48.2%).

codes.summary: A very high MRSA prevalence of 79% among S. aureus isolates from SSIs was found, suggesting significant healthcare-associated transmission and a high burden of resistant pathogens.

evidence_quotes.quote: The MRSA prevalence rate (79%) also seems to suggest healthcare-associated infections...

codes.summary: Inappropriate antibiotic use, particularly the administration of prophylaxis post-operatively rather than pre-incision and the use of third-generation cephalosporins, is cited as a likely driver of high infection and resistance rates.

evidence_quotes.quote: ...inappropriate use of antibiotics, particularly third-generation cephalosporins.
no consistent protocol for the administration of antibiotic prophylaxis is available and usually antimicrobials are administered after the operation...

codes.summary: Likely contamination in the operating theatre and overcrowding in wards are highlighted as potential drivers of nosocomial infections.

evidence_quotes.quote: ...probable contamination in the theatre during the operations.
The overcrowding of labour rooms and post-delivery ward...need to be addressed to decrease the occurrence of nosocomial infections...

codes.summary: Surgical procedures performed by less experienced junior doctors were associated with a higher risk of SSI, indicating that staff training and supervision are important determinants of surgical outcomes.

evidence_quotes.quote: Univariate analysis suggested that surgical procedures performed by interns were associated with a higher risk of SSI compared with those performed by senior doctors...

codes.summary: The facility lacks both antimicrobial stewardship programs and consistent protocols for surgical antibiotic prophylaxis, highlighting a need to review and implement national and local guidelines.

evidence_quotes.quote: ...the lack of antimicrobial stewardship, need to be addressed to decrease the occurrence of nosocomial infections and the burden of resistant bacteria.
This ﬁnding may highlight a substantial need to review national guidelines and internal operative protocols on the management of pregnant women undergoing CS.

funding_sources: Italian Development Cooperation e Ministry of Foreign Affairs AID9562
‘Ricerca Corrente’ of the Italian Ministry of Health

notes_flags.detail: High rate of loss to follow-up (197/664, 29.7%), which could introduce significant selection bias. Authors state no differences in baseline characteristics were found, but data were not shown.
Detailed antimicrobial susceptibility testing results for specific pathogen-antibiotic pairs are not provided, except for the MRSA rate among S. aureus isolates.
Multivariate analysis for risk factors was mentioned as being non-significant but the model, covariates, and results were not presented.
The sum of SSI types (superficial=138, deep=69, organ/space=5) is 212. The total SSIs reported is 225. Table I notes 13 cases of unknown type, which accounts for the difference.

Suture type Interrupted 190 (59) 137 (41) Ref.

An intervention to implement evidence-based revisions of the surgical procedures and antibiotic prophylaxis at the DRRH Gynaecology and Obstetrics Department is continuing.

At the DRRH, as in other Tanzanian settings, no consistent protocol for the administration of antibiotic prophylaxis is available and usually antimicrobials are administered after the operation; the type, dosage, and timing depends on the individual clinician’s preference.
Univariate analysis suggested that surgical procedures performed by interns were associated with a higher risk of SSI compared with those performed by senior doctors...

The detected incidence rate of post-CS SSI was extremely high, at 48.2%. A recent report from Tanzania documented a more than four-fold lower incidence of post-CS SSI compared with our study (10.9% vs 48.2%).
The MRSA prevalence rate (79%) also seems to suggest healthcare-associated infections...
...inappropriate use of antibiotics, particularly third-generation cephalosporins.
The overcrowding of labour rooms and post-delivery ward, and the lack of antimicrobial stewardship, need to be addressed to decrease the occurrence of nosocomial infections...
This ﬁnding may highlight a substantial need to review national guidelines and internal operative protocols on the management of pregnant women undergoing CS.
This survey was supported by grants from the Italian Development Cooperation e Ministry of Foreign Affairs AID9562 and ‘Ricerca Corrente’ of the Italian Ministry of Health.

A total of 664 patients who delivered by CS during the study period were enrolled. Of these, 197 (29.7%) did not attend any clinical visit after the surgical procedure and all attempts to contact them by telephone failed; hence, no outcome was available.
None of these variables remained signﬁcant in multivariate analysis.
